Award.AwardTitle: Seismicity and Fault Structure of Oceanic Detachment Faults
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plate rifting at oceanic spreading centers occurs through a combination of faulting and injection of magma, both of which relieve built-up stress associated with global tectonic forces. At times faulting can dominate, leading to sustained slip along a single plane for over a million years. Seafloor formed during such periods of 'detachment faulting' differs from the typical, linear volcanic hills that are ubiquitous on the seafloor. Instead domal features, with up to a few km seafloor relief, develop as initially deep rock is unroofed by relative motion across the fault. This study aims to show how detachment faults behave seismically- where small earthquakes occur with depth along the fault and how that activity varies laterally. New insights gained in this study could be applicable to other regions where extensional tectonic stress and magmatism occur, such as parts of the U.S. Basin and Range province. This study is jointly supported by the Marine Geology and Geophysics Program and the International Science and Engineering section of NSF.

Analysis of microseismicity data recorded during 6-month deployments of ocean bottom seismometers at 13째N and 26째N on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge will be conducted in order to elucidate fault activity at young oceanic core complexes. The 13째N work is one component of broader UK-French-US collaborative project; the 26째N effort focuses on earthquakes intermediate in size between events that were previously studied; new results will focus in detail on crust shallower than 3 km for the first time. The seismicity patterns of these two areas, that both host oceanic core complexes, will be compared. Documentation of the distribution of earthquakes, and possibly some focal mechanisms, aims to assess how detachment faults behave in 3-D and what the implications might be in terms of fault strength and spatial/temporal evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Detachment faults are long-lived extensional faults that are scientifically important because they represent a poorly understood mode of creating the Earth's crust, they expose material from the Earth's deep interior on the seafloor, and they generate unique types of hydrothermal systems that often contain large amounts of free hydrogen, which in turn generates unique biological communities. We analyzed seismic data from 25 stations deployed on the seafloor around an active detachment fault in order to understand the mechanical behavior of these systems. Our most important finding was that the detachment faulting process at our study site (13deg-20 min North on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge) generates large amounts of compressive seismicity. This was unexpected considering that the faulting system is extensional, and led to the hypothesis that bending stresses generated by exhumation of the fault footwall cause compressive failure in the lower portions of the newly created tectonic plate. This hypothesis is consistent with prevailing "rolling hinge" models of the detachment faulting process, and indicates that bending stresses may play a larger than expected role in the faulting and deformation process. The implications of this discovery are still being considered. A second outcome of our work is the observation that the detachment fault does not slip via a large number of small earthquakes on the shallow, low-angle portion of the fault zone. Previous studies had failed to detect earthquakes in this region, but the networks utilized in these studies were too sparse to rule out the possibility of small magnitude seismicity. The dense network that we deployed also failed to detect any such seismicity, which strongly suggests that this shallow portion of the fault zone slips via infrequent, but large earthquakes.
